title: Johnny Seven (actor)
text:
John Anthony Fetto, II (February 23, 1926 – January 22, 2010), known professionally as Johnny Seven, was an American <a href="character%20actor">character actor</a> who appeared in 26 films and approximately 600 television shows during his career, which spanned more than 40 years. His credits included a recurring role as Lt. Carl Reese on the 1968–1975 <a href="NBC">NBC</a> television series "<a href="Ironside%20%28TV%20series%29">Ironside</a>" and the 1960 film "<a href="The%20Apartment">The Apartment</a>".
Early life.
Seven was born in <a href="Bay%20Ridge%2C%20Brooklyn">Bay Ridge, Brooklyn</a>. His parents, who were <a href="Italians">Italian</a> immigrants, also had five daughters. He began acting and singing as a teenager. He served with the <a href="United%20States%20Army">United States Army</a> in the <a href="Philippines">Philippines</a> during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> and performed with the <a href="United%20Service%20Organizations">United Service Organizations</a> (USO). Fetto earned his nickname "Johnny Seven" while serving in the Army and kept it as his <a href="stage%20name">stage name</a> following the end of the war.
Career.
Seven began his acting career in <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a> theater. He portrayed Karl Matuschka, the brother in-law of <a href="Shirley%20MacLaine">Shirley MacLaine</a>'s character, in "The Apartment". In the film, he punches out the character played by <a href="Jack%20Lemmon">Jack Lemmon</a>. His other film credits include "<a href="The%20Last%20Mile%20%281959%20film%29">The Last Mile</a>" (1959), "<a href="Guns%20of%20the%20Timberland">Guns of the Timberland</a>" (1960), "<a href="What%20Did%20You%20Do%20in%20the%20War%2C%20Daddy%3F">What Did You Do in the War, Daddy?</a>" (1968) and "<a href="Murder%20at%20the%20World%20Series">Murder at the World Series</a>" (1977). Seven co-wrote, produced, directed, and starred in "<a href="Navajo%20Run">Navajo Run</a>", his <a href="Western%20%28genre%29">western</a> <a href="independent%20film">independent film</a> released in 1964.
On television, in addition to "Ironside", he was cast in a spin-off series, "<a href="Amy%20Prentiss">Amy Prentiss</a>". His other television credits included roles on "<a href="Rescue%208">Rescue 8</a>", "<a href="The%20Man%20from%20Blackhawk">The Man from Blackhawk</a>", "<a href="Bonanza">Bonanza</a>", "<a href="Hennesey">Hennesey</a>", "<a href="The%20Everglades%20%28TV%20series%29">The Everglades</a>", "<a href="Gunsmoke">Gunsmoke</a>", "<a href="CHiPs">CHiPs</a>", "<a href="Naked%20City%20%28TV%20series%29">Naked City</a>", "<a href="Mickey%20Spillane%27s%20Mike%20Hammer%20%281958%20TV%20series%29">Mickey Spillane's Mike Hammer</a>", "<a href="The%20Phil%20Silvers%20Show">The Phil Silvers Show</a>", "<a href="Batman%20%28TV%20series%29">Batman</a>" (episodes 25 and 26), "<a href="Death%20Valley%20Days">Death Valley Days</a>", "<a href="Peter%20Gunn">Peter Gunn</a>", "<a href="The%20Untouchables%20%281959%20TV%20series%29">The Untouchables</a>", "<a href="The%20Rockford%20Files">The Rockford Files</a>", "<a href="The%20Wild%20Wild%20West">The Wild Wild West</a>","<a href="The%20Rookies">The Rookies</a>" and "<a href="Charlie%27s%20Angels">Charlie's Angels</a>".
In 1962, he was cast as farmer Carlo Farelli in the episode "The Last Shot" on the <a href="television%20syndication">syndicated</a> <a href="anthology%20series">anthology series</a>, "<a href="Death%20Valley%20Days">Death Valley Days</a>," hosted by <a href="Stanley%20Andrews">Stanley Andrews</a>. In the story line, Carlo eyes saloon singer Della (<a href="Grace%20Lee%20Whitney">Grace Lee Whitney</a> as a wife but soon encounters competition from another suitor. 
In addition to his acting career, Seven also owned a <a href="real%20estate">real estate</a> business in the <a href="San%20Fernando%20Valley">San Fernando Valley</a>.
Death.
Seven died of <a href="complication%20%28medicine%29">complications</a> from <a href="lung%20cancer">lung cancer</a> at <a href="Providence%20Holy%20Cross%20Medical%20Center">Providence Holy Cross Medical Center</a> in <a href="Mission%20Hills%2C%20Los%20Angeles">Mission Hills, California</a>, on January 22, 2010, at the age of 83. He was survived by his wife of sixty years, Edith. and his son, John Anthony Fetto, III, an attorney in <a href="Walnut%20Creek%2C%20California">Walnut Creek</a>, California. His memorial service was held at St. John Baptist de La Salle Parish in <a href="Granada%20Hills%2C%20California">Granada Hills</a>, California, on February 6, 2010.
